values.alignmentText: Bordeaux’s Mérignac aeronautics hub and fintech firms like CDiscount run .NET microservices, and remote roles tied to Paris scale-ups let Trey stay in the Gironde while collaborating with larger teams.
Atlantic winds usually hold PM2.5 near 12 µg/m³, yet harvest season dust and ring-road traffic trigger occasional NO₂ alerts, so the family keeps air purifiers handy.
Cafés such as Le Labo du Jeu, the Animasia festival, and wine-country geek collectives foster steady tabletop meetups for Trey.
Plan for €3,000–€3,400 a month: renovated stone townhouses rent around €1,600, and tourism-influenced prices make dining out pricier than Nantes.
Airbus, Dassault, and Thales sponsor engineers regularly, while scale-ups in the French Tech Bordeaux network occasionally back Tech Visa hires—smaller wineries seldom do.
Autumn stays gentle, from 24 °C (75 °F) in September to 13 °C (55 °F) by November with light rain, perfect for vineyard hikes.
Stone row houses in Chartrons or Caudéran command €1,500–€1,700 and require guarantors, while new builds in Euratlantique ease supply—still more affordable than Paris but rising fast.
Tourism and wine trade bring more English speakers, yet administrative offices remain French-first, so daily life still leans on the family’s language learning.
French Tech Bordeaux, queer collective Le Girofard, and active parenting forums create a friendly landing pad once the family joins local associations.
The SMIC sits near €1,766 gross per month in 2024, supporting local hires better than many EU peers but still tight for big-city rent if we rely solely on one salary.
Le Rocher de Palmer, La Rock School Barbey, and riverside guinguettes deliver live music, with trams running late on key lines for easy date nights.
Weekends buzz around Place de la Victoire and Bassins à Flot, while suburban districts quiet early; safety stays manageable with standard precautions.
Bordeaux Games and the Bordeaux Geek Festival convene studios and students, keeping the indie scene collaborative and visible.
Asobo Studio, Ubisoft Bordeaux, and Motion Twin headline a dense talent pool alongside indies like Shiro Games—ideal partners for Trey’s projects.
Tram commutes under 35 minutes, long lunches, and a strong café culture balance productive weeks with relaxed evenings by the Garonne.
Tram lines A–D, dedicated bike lanes, and TER links cover daily mobility; peak-hour crowding and early shutdowns on some routes mean occasional planning.
Shiro Games, CDiscount, and health-tech startups use Rails, and remote-first Paris companies recruit in Bordeaux, though roles remain fewer than .NET openings.
Bordeaux centers feel secure, yet nightlife hubs see pickpockets and scooter theft; vigilance around tram hubs keeps risks low for the kids.
Public schools perform well, with International School of Bordeaux and Montessori options covering bilingual education when needed.
Winters hover around 8 °C (46 °F) with drizzle, summers reach 28 °C (82 °F) and occasional 38 °C (100 °F) heatwaves, so shade and shutters help manage spikes.
April–May highs climb to 20 °C (68 °F) with crisp mornings near 8 °C (46 °F), inviting park time before the tourist rush.
Typical highs sit at 27–29 °C (81–84 °F), but late July canicules push past 35 °C (95 °F) for several days, making fans and shutters essential.
Senior engineers earn €55k–€65k with bonuses; cost of living is lower than Paris yet rising, so negotiating relocation packages matters.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries

values.alignmentText: Sizeable Anglophone communities tied to the wine trade and universities help newcomers settle, and Bordeaux City Hall’s Welcome Office guides families through paperwork.
UNESCO riverfronts, wine country bike loops, and ocean day trips to Arcachon Bay keep the family’s weekend calendar full.

Lower-income families can make it work but face long waitlists or limited options in desirable neighborhoods. Minimum Wage at 7/10, Housing Situation at 6/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Comfortable living is possible but major purchases or travel demand careful planning and occasional sacrifices. Typical Software Salaries at 6/10, Housing Situation at 6/10, and Work-Life Balance at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

High-end living is feasible yet demands planning around limited providers or exclusive networks. Housing Situation at 6/10, Private Education at 6/10, and Family Life at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Large rentals appear occasionally and move fast, demanding premium rent or broker connections. Housing Situation at 6/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

Interactions can be efficient yet emotionally flat; kindness takes effort to elicit. Community Vibes at 6/10, Nightlife Culture at 6/10, and Common Hobbies at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for surface interaction norms.

Boundaries are understood yet alcohol-fueled scenes need watchfulness. Sex (Attitudes) at 7/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 8/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for flirting boundaries & consent culture.

Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere. Sex (Attitudes) at 7/10, Nightlife & Music at 7/10, and Community Vibes at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Tight quarters and spontaneous touch are common; advocating for space is a regular task. Community Vibes at 6/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 7/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for personal space & touch norms.

Sidewalks cover key areas but drivers often rush, so we stay alert with children. Public Transportation at 7/10, Housing Situation at 6/10, and Nature Access at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

Processed foods are common but balanced by strong fresh markets. Cost of Living (Optional) at 6/10, Community Health Consciousness at 8/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for processed food saturation.

We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically. Nightlife & Music at 7/10, Common Hobbies at 7/10, and Meetups & Communities at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Moderate obesity levels exist but community efforts keep trends stable. Community Health Consciousness at 8/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for obesity rate.

Market depends on a few key industries, so we maintain contingency plans. Economic Health at 7/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 7/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for broader job market resilience.
